questions.question: I don't know ...................................... I would get the job.
questions.description: If or whether can introduce an indirect question.

questions.question: They cancelled the match .............................. bad weather.
He still drives that old car ............................... he has enough money to buy a new car.
questions.description: Either though or even though is possible here. Even though is more emphatic than though.

questions.question: I learned Spanish ............................... be able to find a job during my stay in Spain.
It seems .................................... somebody had opened the door.
Break the glass ................................. fire.
questions.description: If is used before a clause. In case of and in the event of are used before a noun.

questions.question: I ordered food online ................................. I didn't have enough time to cook.
It rained several times ................................ the night.
We can't leave ............................... he returns.
questions.description: Till and until mean the same till is more common in an informal style.

questions.question: They couldn't save her .............................. their best efforts.
questions.description: Either despite or in spite of is possible here.

questions.question: ………………………… hard you may try, you will not finish that task.
questions.description: However hard means the same as it doesn't matter how hard.

questions.question: She looked pale ……………………………. she had seen a ghost.
